text: Ian, Asela, thanks so much for joining us
in the AWS studio.
Thanks for having us.
Thank you.
Let's jump right in with a few intros.

Ian, can you tell us a
little bit about yourself?
Yeah, sure.

So I'm the Senior Vice
President of Asia Pacific

and I've been working with
Axiata Group and Dialog
for about 12 years now in that role.
Over to you Asela.

I'm the Group Chief Information
Officer of Dialog Axiata,
and I think we've been having a very long

and I would say mutually
beneficial relationship.
Everybody likes a good origin story.
Can you tell us a little bit about it?

So, with CSG, I think back
then it was called Intec,

if I'm not mistaken.
[Ian] Yeah, long time ago.
[Asela] So it was about 17 years ago,

we first ventured into
interconnect building at that time.

And I think that relationship
has continued today
and we've gone on to much more,
I think a broader scope today.
Let's fast forward to today.
What does the partnership look like?
Today, it's very much evolved
into a much broader wholesale routing

and still based on that
carrier to carrier settlement
but with much bigger ambitions,
particularly with Asela leading, you know,
a move to the cloud.
It's very exciting what the future holds,
both for Dialog, and for our partnership
with ourselves and AWS.

Well, we obviously want
to hear a little bit more
about your journey to the cloud.

Tell us about some of the
challenges you experienced
and how you were able to overcome them.
Yeah, so we started off
about three or four years ago, actually.
It was a very small step at first
but now if you look at cloud ecosystem,

we moved some of our BSS
loads, and then as Ian said,

the wholesale and interconnect
settlement piece as well.
But one of the main challenges I think was
about scalability really, because on-prem,

we were stuck and we had
a lot of issues in terms
of meeting those customer demands.

So it was really about the
challenge of scalability,
and embracing new technology
that the cloud brings to the table.
So how did AWS unlock that scalability

for you across your cloud
transformation journey?

Yes, I think there was
a lot of enablement.
I think if I kind of compare some

of the other cloud partners,
what AWS brought to the table
was a lot of help, a lot of handholding

during those initial
periods, which really kind

of ignited a flame in the
whole developer community.

And then we thought, obviously
with the benefits that we saw
that cloud brings to the table,
today we have we have been able
to scale quite a bit actually.

So you mentioned the developer
community, has me curious,
when you think about the impact

of this move to the cloud,
was it purely technical?

Was it about cost savings,
or was it also cultural,
the impact of the developer community
and the seamlessness that was unlocked?
Yeah, absolutely right.
I think the cultural transformation

was a little bit different and
difficult at the beginning.
And like I said, that's
where AWS really helped us and guided us.

But I think that agility is
what it brings to the table,

because like I said, when
you are in an on-prem
and when you're kind of stuck,
you are limited by that box, right?

But here, with more and
more demands coming in,
you are able to kind of broaden that view.
And from a cost point of view,
the scaling up and scaling down
has also really helped us.
So with Axiata's journey in mind, Ian,

let's talk a little
bit about CSG strategy.
When working with AWS,
how did you approach the collaboration?

Yeah, it's been a really
interesting journey.

So we've partnered with
AWS now for a long time,

and as Asela mentioned,
we'd inherited a number

of legacy on-premise
installations with our customers,
and we look to digitize their journeys.

And so one of the
businesses that CSG bought,
the Intec business that Asela mentioned,
it is the wholesale number one provider
in the telecoms industry globally.
And what we've been working with AWS on

is basically moving and
digitizing all those platforms

around the world to basically
come into the public cloud.
And as Asela mentions it,
it not only gives you great time to market

and reduces the operational
load and the need for CapEx,
but it also gives that scalability

that Asela mentioned. So if
you want to grow your business,

now we're talking about adding
more modules on, you know
for things like 5G roaming with BCE,
enterprise settlements, a bit more
that we'll come onto in a minute.
But we've really worked

with AWS to transform
what was a legacy area
of telecoms into the cloud.
And that's our vision for the whole of CSG

is to be the number one
Cloud SaaS platform provider.

And AWS is absolutely fundamental
to our strategy for that.

You mentioned digitization
of platforms. I want to

go back to some of the
challenges you've been

seeing across your
customers more generally.

Does the scalability piece
that was mentioned earlier,

does that align with what you've
been seeing from customers?
[Ian] Oh hundred percent.

So, as Asela was mentioning,
you're limited by the box.

If you are committed to
an on-prem application

then you know, how you can
scale it is very difficult
because you need more CapEx,
you've got to make that decision point,

you've got to step up
in costs before you get
the scale of the subscribers onto it.
Whereas with something like
our public cloud offering with AWS,

you can basically
horizontally scale seamlessly
and match your costs to your revenue

and your business case
becomes a lot simpler.

And with something like
application managed services

where we jointly host and
manage that application,
you can just horizontally scale
and it enables new features to be dropped
on a quarterly basis.
It enables you to enter new verticals,
it enables you to bring on more customers
and manage your costs as you do that.

I've now heard both of
you talk about CapEx,

so I think we got to
dive a little bit deeper
into that. Over to you Asela,

when you think about the trade
off between CapEx and OpEx,

how did your cloud
transformation specifically

in this domain help you realize
your ultimate business case?
Well, I think first is,
if you look at the traditional model,

you have to do these
massive kind of overhauling
of systems right?
And that causes disruption, not just
from a CapEx point of view,
but if you look at the business ecosystem
because you are now doing almost like
a lift and shift, right?

You have one system and
you completely uproot it
and you put a new system in place.
Whereas in this model, like what Ian said,
it gives you the opportunity to

keep incrementally kind
of building these features
as you go along.
So that itself is kind of a relief
because you don't go through this massive,
you know, chaos, so to speak,
when you want to do a big system change.

And I think if you look
at what we had before,
we had this interconnect system,

then we had this least
cost routing system,
and we had a settlement system.
So these were three different parts
in really one ecosystem.
So what CSG really brought
to the table was a combined platform

which brings all of these
three pieces together

and it kind of smoothed the
digitization process itself
because from an operational perspective,

otherwise the overhead of
managing these three systems,

all three systems on-prem, and
from business point of view,
reconciling across all these systems

was really not the best
way of doing things.

So I think again, that's
why we see a lot of benefits
in bringing this to the table.
Yeah, I'd just like to add on the burden
of a traditional on-premise upgrade

on an operator and
selling it for the vendor,

our main cloud application
Ascendon, which is native in AWS,
every 90 days there's a new feature drop.
And if you think of that compared
to a traditional billing system
that an operator might have,
it's just a different world.

And the thought of you
having having to plan a major

billing upgrade for your
B2C and B2B business,

versus just quarterly
drops coming in seamlessly,
it's a game changer.
I could even see the smile
on Asela's face when he talked

about the relief...
[Asela] Of course.
[Robert] ...of that digitization afforded.

Another benefit that I think
is probably worth calling

out is being able to expand
to new domains altogether.
Ian, talk to me about that

and how your platform
helps drive that expansion
and what did you observe
from the benefits, maybe after?
Yeah, absolutely.

So we mentioned a little bit
earlier about 5G roaming.
So we're already providing with Asela
the roaming capability with 5G coming in.
You need BCE roaming
in Sri Lanka where Dialog's based,

there's been some economic
issues with tourism,
but as it comes back with 5G,
they're going to need that.
Well, we can just drop that in,
in the cloud very seamlessly.

Secondly, marketplaces
as Asela was mentioning,
the enterprise space in 5G is critical.
Particularly in the SMB space,
you need a marketplace

to cross-sell and settle
with all your partners.
We can achieve that

by dropping a new module
into the AWS Cloud, right?
And again, it's not a huge decision
with a huge CapEx burden.

It's seamlessly dropping
that new capability in
and it just enables business innovation
in a way that you never could on-premise.

Well said, and it's that
drag and drop feature,

low-code, no-code that is
giving operators the flexibility
that they're ultimately looking for.

Maybe we talk a little
bit more about this like

marketplace feature,
marketplaces and ecosystems.

As you think about your strategy
for your global customers,
why is that so important

and how have you
experienced that marketplace
manifest itself with your end customers?
Yeah, so in Sri Lanka

we have API monetization
framework in place,
very successful actually.
So there's lot of these on one side,

developer communities who
build these applications.
And then there are set of SMEs
who basically consume these applications.
So the settlement piece for all of these,

so you have the application
provide on one side
you have the consumer on the other side,

and then you have to operate
on the other side, right?

So all these three have
to kind of come together
obviously for it to work.

And settlement is an
important piece, right?

Because obviously if these
guys don't get paid on time,

if you don't have transparency
of the transactions,
then they're not going to like it.
So what we are trying to do actually

with this platform is
take that conversation
and see how we can seamlessly do it.
Because today, again, the time it takes

for us to do it
semi-automatically, so to speak,
is not the best way of doing it.
So these are fantastic opportunities

and those discussions are
happening as we speak,
to use this platform, to make that happen
seamlessly, it's a zero touch.

I mean we use the word very
very loosely these days,
so trying to bring zero touch
into this whole partner ecosystem.

Yeah, I'd love to
emphasize that even more.
And there is no way

if you want to drive
your enterprise business,

which you have to do to
get the return on 5G,
other than have, as Asela said,
an integrated, digitized marketplace

that both makes the
offers to your customers
and then settles with your partners
with no human intervention.
Because if you think of the thousands
of offers in your product catalog

that you have to publish
into your marketplace,
and then as Asela said,
if you're not paying your developers,
you're not even going to have any offers.
And by the way,

think of the potential
for billing disputes

between thousands of sales to
thousands of small businesses

and then settlements back
to thousands of providers
of applications, it's just horrific.
So the thought of trying to manage that
with any kind of manual intervention,

if you don't truly digitize,
and that means being

in the public cloud, that
means low-code, no-code,
that means that true end-to-end workflow

with a digital product
catalog and open APIs,
then yeah, I wouldn't want to try
and run a telco marketplace without that.

I'm curious, Asela, you
mentioned API monetization.
Any best practices for other operators
looking to empower API-based monetization?
What have been your experiences there?
Yeah, I think initially it's all again
about how you engage.

So it's about how you
bring these people in,

because sometimes they
also don't understand
the capability that is out there.

So at Dialog, what we
did probably successfully
in those initial informative years

is that there was, again
lot of interactions,
lot of small community events

that were hosted and
where people were educated
in terms of those capabilities.

And then once you build
that critical mass,

they themselves feel kind
of take it out there.
It's like almost vital marketing, right?

But again, like AWS helped us
at those informative years,

for this source you need
a little bit of a spark.
So you have to fight to be ignited.
You need people to engage.

It's about constant
engagement to make it work.

Let's zoom out for a
second, maybe to you Ian

where's the future of the
collaboration between AWS,
CSG, and Dialog Axiata ultimately going?

Right, so that's actually
a really strong question

because, so Dialog is
part of Axiata group,
which is a much broader group.
What we're able to do with Dialog,

and Dialog is a very innovative
part of Axiata group,
is innovate, experiment, prove out,
and then provide to the rest of the group
a single settlements engine

so that the capability
that Asela is building

is very easily capable
of giving that scale
across the whole of Axiata group.
So imagine a single settlements engine
that is able to settle all the operators.

Now they can have their
own instance obviously

or their own tenant if
you like to do that.
So you have segregation of reporting
and all the requirements that are needed,

but all the operators within
Axiata group could easily,

because of the scalability
of AWS and CSG's partnership,
just roll out that solution.

And there you go, you've
digitized basically
six operating companies after Dialog being
the thought leader within the group.
[Asela] Good.

[Robert] I want to give you
the final word here, Asela.

A big theme for us this
year is next level.
What is the next level of Dialog Axiata?

So I think we are having
a lot of internal debate

about this whole
techco/telco conversation.
So, I mean Ian had mentioned also
about the whole platform ecosystem.

So I think we feel that
telco needs to kind of

evolve into a place where
APIs, platforms, ecosystems -
because traditional telco is kind
of getting stagnated, right?
So if we want to go to that next level,

that whole techo
conversation has to kind of,
maybe amplify a little bit more.
And we need to build ecosystems

where various partners can
come together and, you know,
we can facilitate that collaboration
to have a win-win model.
Absolutely.

This is a great conversation,
I had a lot of fun.
Thanks for stopping by the AWS studio.

[Ian] Thanks very much.
[Asela] Thanks so much.
